awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a High Resolution Mass Spectrometer for Education and Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. The University of Tampa is acquiring a high resolution mass spectrometer equipped with an orbitrap analyzer, a direct analysis in real time (DART) interface and an ultrahigh pressure liquid chromatography (UPLC) unit to support Kenyon Evans-Nguyen and colleagues Kelly Deister, Michelle Crosby and Christine Theodore. In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species in complex samples.  An instrument with a high resolution liquid chromatography sector provides additional structural identification power by separating mixtures of compounds before they reach the mass spectrometer. The direct analysis in real time is an ion source that produces electronically or vibronically excited-state species such as helium, argon or nitrogen that ionize atmospheric molecules which then undergo ion-molecule reactions with the sample molecules to be analyzed. The instrument broadens participation by involving diverse students with this modern analytical technique. It is extensively used to train undergraduate and high school students and by collaborators at neighboring institutions.

The award of the UPLC-MS/MS system is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It is especially useful for quantifying, characterizing compounds to develop advanced data sets to aid natural products research. The instrumentation is also used for characterizing the spatial and temporal distributions of contaminants in Tampa Bay.  The instrument also serves researchers characterizing and analyzing new psychoactive substances (NPS), also known as substances of abuse, in biological specimens. An important use is for the development and construction of ambient ionization sources capable of combined molecular, organic, and elemental analysis for applications in forensic science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
A high-resolution mass spectrometer instrument was acquired using the awarded funds. The instrument was applied to research and teaching in  forensic toxicology, forensic chemistry, environmental chemistry, and drug discovery. Undergraduate students were trained in the use of this cutting-edge instrumentation to analyze drugs in bodily fluids such as blood or urine. New teaching laboratories, based on analysis of caffeine and related compounds in single-serving coffee pods, were developed to train students in drug analysis techniques with the instrument. New methods to sample forensic evidence were developed that allowed chemical analysis of samples without damaging or touching them. Fingerprint and touch DNA evidence on the surface of samples is often destroyed during chemical analysis for drugs or explosives, but with this method chemical analysis is achieved while preserving underlying evidence. Additionally, a new system for the chemical analysis of fingerprints was developed based on the actual workflow of forensic laboratories. Fingerprints are typically developed by "fuming" them with cyanoacrylate (superglue) followed by staining them with a red dye for visualization. A visible MALDESI system was constructed to probe compounds in the red dye-stained processed fingerprints. After initial testing, this system could be used to analyze and visualize chemical compounds such as drugs and explosives present in the fingerprints of suspects.  

The instrument acquired with this award was used to study pollution due to pharmaceutical compounds and PFOS in surface waters of the Tampa Bay area. Indicators of human pharmaceutical activity, including caffeine, acetaminophen, carbamazepine, DEET, and nicotine, were found in several stations along the Hillsborough and Alafia Rivers. Current work is focused on determining amounts of PFOS, a pollutant traced to non-stick coatings, firefighter foams, and various consumer products along these rivers.  

Marine natural products are a prolific source of potential new pharmaceutical drug leads; this instrument was used to analyze complex mixtures of marine bacteria to search for potential new drugs. A methodology was developed to help visualize the complex data sets that result from analyzing the myriad of compounds present in these marine bacteria extracts to assist in the search for new drugs.

The instrument was used extensively in the hands-on training of undergraduates through four different laboratory courses spanning forensic science, analytical chemistry, and organic chemistry. 

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2024
Modified by: Kenyon M Evans-Nguyen
